creator: ragaller@apache.org
text:
In authoring/site the workflow state of a document (and it's children) is
currently left unchanged after a «copy/paste» action - it should be set to
«authoring» after paste.

The actions «cut and move(up/down)» should be disabled for documents (and it's
children) if the have a workflow state other than «authoring».

After «copy» there is a Infotext saying that the «document» can be pasted to a
location of your choosing - in case the document has children i suggest to write
«subtree» or «document and it's children».

Jürgen Ragaller

creator: andreas@apache.org
text:
(In reply to comment #0)
> In authoring/site the workflow state of a document (and it's children) is
> currently left unchanged after a «copy/paste» action - it should be set to
> «authoring» after paste.
> 
> The actions «cut and move(up/down)» should be disabled for documents (and it's
> children) if the have a workflow state other than «authoring».

I just thought about it - actually, what we have here, is a change to the site
structure and not to the documents itself. This is quite a new issue, since in
1.2 the documents were affected (moved) when their location in the site
structure changed. Would it make sense to apply a workflow to the site structure
as well?

(In reply to comment #2)
> (In reply to comment #0)
> > In authoring/site the workflow state of a document (and it's children) is
> > currently left unchanged after a «copy/paste» action - it should be set to
> > «authoring» after paste.
> > 
> > The actions «cut and move(up/down)» should be disabled for documents (and it's
> > children) if the have a workflow state other than «authoring».
> 
> I just thought about it - actually, what we have here, is a change to the site
> structure and not to the documents itself. This is quite a new issue, since in
> 1.2 the documents were affected (moved) when their location in the site
> structure changed.

You mean, that the changes in the structure are instantly «live» in 1.2?

> Would it make sense to apply a workflow to the site structure as well? 

Would this mean, that a user with the appropriate rights (e.g. a admin or
reviewer) could rearrange the sitetree (even for live documents maybe) and click
on a link «update site structure» that only affects the sitetree.xml? The
advantage of this could be, that one does not have to deactivate a tree before
moving it («hot rearranging»). If «cut» is chosen, there needs to be a check
that a «paste» occurs after.

I think the consequences of actions on the site structure have to be very clear
to the average user (or let's say at least a site admin with intermediate
knowledge).

Please be aware that I am new to this and I'm only thinking loud here...
creator: ragaller@apache.org
andreas@apache.org
text:
(In reply to comment #3)

[...]

> > 1.2 the documents were affected (moved) when their location in the site
> > structure changed.
> 
> You mean, that the changes in the structure are instantly «live» in 1.2?

No, but the documents had to be published again because their physical location
changed. In 1.4, the phyisical representation of the document is not affected at
all when its location in the site structure changes (a good example of SoC).


> > Would it make sense to apply a workflow to the site structure as well? 
> 
> Would this mean, that a user with the appropriate rights (e.g. a admin or
> reviewer) could rearrange the sitetree (even for live documents maybe) and click
> on a link «update site structure» that only affects the sitetree.xml?

Yes, or whatever type of site structure is used.

> The
> advantage of this could be, that one does not have to deactivate a tree before
> moving it («hot rearranging»). If «cut» is chosen, there needs to be a check
> that a «paste» occurs after.

"cut" itself doesn't do anything - the "paste" triggers a move operation.


> I think the consequences of actions on the site structure have to be very clear
> to the average user (or let's say at least a site admin with intermediate
> knowledge).
> 
> Please be aware that I am new to this and I'm only thinking loud here...

Sure, it's very interesting to hear about a user's point of view. IMO it makes
more sense to keep the site structure and documents separated also in the GUI,
to keep implementation and usage consistent. But I'm very interested in the
opinions of other users+devs.

creator: andreas@apache.org
text: I started a thread on users@lenya.
Cut and move up/down are now disabled if a live version exists.
